It's just a consequence you made up essentially

So someone breaking your window and having to pay for its repair isn't punishment, it's a logical consequence from the offense. But a dude breaking your window and then you lock them in your basement for 3 nights, that's punishment, bc it logically doesn't follow from the offense

Honestly? I think as a rule, punishment is just a bad way of responding to undesirable behavior. And by punishment I don't mean consequences or accountability, I mean the specific and intentional levying of harm in response to a perceived moral slight
And instead embrace bursts of productivity followed by rest and leisure and individualized schedules
So should school start at 9 am? Sure, but the whole concept the school day needs to be abolished too. In the future, let's rely less on standardized schedules and constant levels of productivity

Obviously there needs to be some sort of timekeeping, like say the science lab is closed during holidays or whatever, but yeah not everyone should be expected to show and leave at the same time. Let people plan their own day and coordinate their plans with others'

Moving on from the fact that school should be abolished, I don't think specific times tables are a good idea. I think kids should control their schedules and if they want to spend 5 hours at the science lab or basketball court, sure why not

Until a kid actually gets hurt, nothing bad happened and I won't get involved. So many adults try to prevent temporary pain before it happens rather than letting kids experience and learn from it. It's not that big a deal, it's just a scrap or a wet slide.

These recess monitors will literally keep the kids who are 8 to 11 years old from going to recess because they are "talking and running". IT'S RECESS. This is the only time of day where they can have unregulated fun & they are excited. Stop controlling them until the last second

No you dummy, she is yelling because she feels unheard and ignored. She is being mean because she doesn't know how to calm down or process her feelings. She is upset and losing control because people think she's crazy when she's literally 8. HELP HER!

So many adults take kids acting out as a personal offense, when I view it as a learning opportunity. A kid was yelling and screaming on the playground a few weeks ago and the adults said "She just thinks she's an adult and can talk to us however she wants."

It's also worth mentioning that for children that genuinely struggle with antisocial behavior, who do wake up and think "I'm gonna be trouble today!", which is under 1%, that is STILL the result of unmet needs and unlearned skills. Help ALL children, even the "bad" ones

And it's worth mentioning that it might just even be misbehavior, it's just behavior we dislike for some reason. There are no bad kids, only bad adults, bad parents, bad teachers, bad role models, and bad authority figures

Children are not psychopathic, some ppl genuinely act like kids wake up in the morning and think to themselves "I'm gonna cause trouble today!" That's not what happens. Children misbehavior is the result of unmet needs and/or unlearned skills, not a deliberate attempt to be "bad"

If their families considering react to the other in negative, harmful, or abusive ways, if society does so, then I imagine the kids will too without realizing it. So if we model how to approach human beings (of ALL kinds and differences) properly culturally, maybe we can fix this

So when kids bully based on race, it seems obvious to me that they are simply repeating the racist messaging constantly broadcast to them by society. So when we take other categories, class, gender, disability, language, nationality, etc. I feel like it's the same way

Like, take race. Kids naturally don't care about race, they come out of the womb without those concepts. But they become racialized in this society and like learning to read, learning to give meaning to race is a lifelong transformation that can only be mitigated

When a child's response to another child who they consider different or "the other" stop becoming curiosity and starts becoming abusive, I have to wonder if that's just bc that's how kids are, or if they are learning that behavior from somewhere else
I guess some part of it is kids not knowing how to react to things outside their norm, but usually gets show curiosity and interest towards those things, albeit perhaps w/o proper boundaries at times
I'm starting to think that most of bullying in school is just kids repeating all of the hierarchies they learn from society thru their families, the media and entertainment, and wider culture

By which I mean challenging the binary of complex and simple society, as well as being inclusive to "simple" societies like nomads, pastoralists, agrarians, and hunter-gatherers, promoting other forms of communication besides written language, and being critical of urbanization

So abolishing civilization doesn't mean there are no complex human societies in the world. We can still have urban areas and symbolic communication*, but we don't need government or hierarchy for social "complexity". We need to move beyond civilization

Right off the bat, from an anarchist perspective, there are two problems: social stratification, or hierarchy, and form of government, which can be interpreted to include the state. By the classical conceptualization of civilization, civilization is inherently anti-anarchist

Definition of civilization:
-Urban development
-Social stratification
-Form of government
-Symbol systems of communication

BUT, if the relationship is not something you want to maintain, if you want nothing to do with this person, forgiveness probably won't be very useful. Sometimes you have to find another verb to describe what you need. Is it forgiveness or unburdening? Forgiveness or no-contact?

Forgiveness is useful if your goal is to maintain a relationship with someone, like possibly a friend or spouse or teacher. If you genuinely want to be cool with them again, then yeah, forgiveness can be very useful...

So fuck bedtimes, abolish school, abolish work, and depathologize just being a night owl. Most kids will not develop a sleep disorder if you let them follow their natural chronotypes and most children will put themselves to bed once they get tired enough. Just let it go

It turns out, there was never anything wrong with me at all, but even with this better sleep schedule, I still feel ashamed when I wake up late, because it's "unproductive" or "wrong", even though I literally accomplish lots of shit during the day.

I did not have insomnia, I just did not sleep when society and school wanted me to. I have a perfectly healthy sleep schedule now, I go to bed around 2 am, wake up around 12 pm, and I feel much happier and well rested than I ever did in the past.

Enforcing a bedtime can shame kids for their natural sleep patterns. So many parents think that if they don't have The Bedtime, their kids were become raging insomniacs. Say it with me: there is a difference between naturally being a night owl and having a sleep disorder!

African French tends to borrow words from local languages or other lingua francas like Arabic, English, or Spanish, so it has a rich morphology and vocabulary that is unique to certain areas, like Nouchi in Cote d'Ivoire

Considering how there are more African French speakers than European ones, and that Africa will be more influential in the future, modern French classes would do well to focus more on African French, which is also way cooler
Nouchi is a valid form/derivation of French and should be studied in French classes

...way to introduce math. In introducing any new subject, you always wow people with the basics, with the cool shit. Talk about infinity, play with magical function boxes, play around with limits and integrals, talk about paradoxes, play with math, don't teach it

@alc_anthro @_Thrill_House_ Does it though? How are zoology and animals the same? And logic is subjective too, different cultures and different individuals have different perspectives on what makes sense and what is possible. If you have different perspectives, it's subjective, that's not bad

The axioms are subjective, the numerals are subjective, so are the symbols, variables, theorems, definitions, and everything else. Math is absolutely based on human subjects which by definition makes it subjective

Treating math as objective is not just demonstrably wrong and not at all how math operates, but it also limits your ability to be a decent theoretical mathematician. A lot of innovations in math came about b.c. someone decided to say "What if x was defined this way"

Imaginary numbers were developed this way. Some dude decided that the solution to x^2=-1 is "i" and "-i" and by defining i as that, the consequences were that now all polynomials below 5 degrees can be solved in radicals, and that we can rotate numbers in a 2d plane
@alc_anthro @_Thrill_House_ Math is a human activity, primarily. If there weren't brains that invented math to describe reality, then there would just be reality that is left undescribed by math.

@alc_anthro @_Thrill_House_ Nope nope nope, zoology and animals aren't equal to each other. And animals are physical objects, math is not a physical object, it can describe or represent nature, but it's not nature itself. This is a false analogy.

Math is subjective. Even seemingly absolute rules not dividing by zero are ignored in some areas (wheel theory, Riemann spheres, limits to an extent), because anything in math can be true depending on how you define it. The only catch is you have to deal with the consequences
@alc_anthro @_Thrill_House_ Would there be math if there weren't minds capable of math?

@TechnoGAUNTLET @_Thrill_House_ That's not what objective is. Objectivity is "not contingent on a subject, i.e. a person". Meters/seconds are contingent on a subject, thus are SUBJECTive. They may be highly consistent across subjective experiences and share a same, similar, or formal definition, but that's it

Just, schools as they currently stand are inherently industrial, capitalist, colonial, and authoritarian, and need to be abolished in favour of a decentralized system of informal education that centers Indigenous & community knowledge and meaningful life experiences
Not to mention that all schools here in the US, Canada, and Mexico are built on stolen Indigenous land, teaching false narratives about that fact

It's based on the idea that someone is not "educated" UNLESS they have a certificate from our colonial institution saying they are educated, invalidating informal knowledge systems like Indigenous knowledge or community relations or even just natural curiosity

Often, formal education has been defined according to what is most beneficial to the status quo, centering colonial, white supremacist, and liberal narratives over anti-colonial, pro-BIPOC, and leftist narratives

Formal education is a Western concept, based on the idea that "true" learning can only be brought about through force and authority, and that people cannot be expected to learn without the compulsory nature of a formal education
#AbolishSchool. I hear a lot of people talk about decolonizing public safety, or healthcare, or the like, but I NEED y'all to make the jump to decolonizing education.
